message.content: This question requires understanding of the relationship between heavy rains and the size of the pond. When there are heavy rains, the pond fills up with water, causing it to swell and flood. As a result, the pond now takes up a greater portion of the yard because the increase in water volume expands its boundaries. Option (A) and (B) are incorrect because they suggest that the pond takes up very little or almost no space, which contradicts the information given in the question. Option (C) is also incorrect because it suggests that the pond takes up a smaller minority, implying that it occupies a smaller portion than before, which is not true.

To answer this question, we need to understand the effects of heavy rains on a pond. When there are heavy rains, the pond fills up with water and swells, causing it to expand in size. Therefore, after heavy rains, the pond will take up a greater portion of the yard. Option (A) is incorrect because the pond would not take up very little space if it has swelled and flooded. Option (B) is also incorrect because if the pond has swelled and flooded, it would not take up almost zero space. Option (C) is incorrect as well because if the pond has expanded, it would not take up a smaller minority of the yard.

Options (A), (B), and (C) are incorrect because they suggest that the pond takes up less space after the heavy rains, which is not the case.
